metadata.titleEn: Data set of driving factors of ecological assets in Qinghai Tibet Plateau from 2000 to 2020
metadata.description: Data set of driving factors of ecological assets in Qinghai Tibet Plateau from 2000 to 2020 contains six categories of ecological asset drivers: topography, climate, soil, vegetation, human activities, and land use types.The NPP of vegetation from the year 2000 to 2015 was obtained from the MOD17A3H dataset, available at https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/, and the spatial and temporal resolutions are 1 km and 1 a, respectively. The datasets utilized for digital elevation model (DEM) were acquired from the Resource and Environmental Science Data Center of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (http://www.resdc.cn/data.aspx) ( G u o e t a l . 2019). The data of 229 meteorological stations in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and its surrounding areas, including parameters like daily precipitation, average daily temperature, daily sunshine hours, etc., was obtained from the China Meteorological Data Network (http://data.cma.cn/). The annual average temperature, annual precipitation, solar radiation, and accumulated temperature were interpolated into grids maintaining the spatial resolution at 1 × 1 km by employing the Cokriging method of ArcGIS 10.3 (Adhikary et al. 2017). The natural breaks method was implemented to classify  different factors, and the average annual precipitation, accumulated temperature, annual average temperature, solar radiation, and elevation were divided into 6 levels, and the slope and aspect were divided into 9 and 10 levels, respectively; population and GDP data were divided into 5 levels. Microsoft Excel was used to remove outliers and to compare and analyze various ecological subregions and different periods.This dataset can be used to support the research on the ecological environment and ecological assets of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau.
metadata.instructions:
File name: 
Terrain factor: It is stored in tif format, and the name of the file is the corresponding terrain factor. For example, Dem.tif means that this file is the elevation data of the study area. 
1.Aspect, aspect, format .tif, resolution is 1km, no unit. 
2.Slope, slope, format .tif, resolution is 1km, unit °. 
3.Dem, altitude, format .tif, resolution is 1km, unit m. 

Climate factors: stored in adf format, the name of the folder is "yyyyxxx", where yyyy represents the year, and xxx represents different climate factors. For example, 2000rainc represents the adf file in this folder to describe the total annual precipitation in the study area in 2000. 
4.jw10c, accumulated temperature>10℃, format.Grid, resolution of 1km, unit of °C, year 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015. 
5.rainc, total annual precipitation, format.Grid, resolution of 1km, unit of mm , year 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015. 
6.tempc, annual average temperature, format.Grid, resolution of 1km, unit ℃, year 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015. 
7.Sunc, sunshine hours, format.Grid , The resolution is 1km, the unit is hour, and the year is 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015. 

Human activity interference factor: stored in tif format, the file names are "GDPyyyy.tif" and "POPyyyy.tif", where yyyy represents year, GDP represents gross domestic product, and POP represents population density, such as GDP2000.tif represents this The file describes the gross product of the 1km grid of the study area in 2000. 
8. GDP, grid data of gross domestic product in kilometers, format.tif, resolution of 1km, unit 10,000 yuan/km2, year 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015. 
9.POP, grid data of population density in kilometers, format. tif, resolution is 1km, unit person/km2, year 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015. 

Land use type: Stored in tif format, the file name is "ldyyyy.tif", where yyyy represents the year, for example, ld2000 represents the file describing the land use type in the study area in 2000. 
10.Ld, land use type, format .tif, resolution 1km, no unit, year 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015, land type refers to the classification system of land use type of Chinese Academy of Sciences. 

Soil: Stored as a tif, the file name is "Soiltype.tif", this file describes the soil type of the study area. 
11.Soiltype, soil type, format .tif, unit no, digitally generated according to the "1:1 million Soil Map of the People's Republic of China" compiled and published by the National Soil Census Office in 1995, using the traditional "soil occurrence classification" system, The basic cartographic unit is a subcategory, with 12 soil classes, 61 soil categories and 227 subcategories. The soil attribute database has 2647 records and 16 attribute data items. 

Vegetation: Stored in tif format, the file name is "yyyyfvc.tif", where yyyy represents the year, for example, 2000fvc.tif represents this file to describe the vegetation coverage in the study area in 2000.
 12. FVC, vegetation coverage, format .tif, resolution 1km, no unit, year 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015. 

Data reading method: All files in the dataset can be directly opened with digital image processing software such as ArcGIS, data The format is tif.

background: Net primary productivity (NPP) denotes the total amount of organic dry matter accumulated by green plants with respect to the unit time and area. NPP is the residual part of the total amount of organic matter produced by photosynthesis after the elimination of autotrophic respiration. As the core content of the carbon budget and climate change research, NPP serves as an important indicator to determine the ecosystem health and sustainable development level. Therefore, analyzing and discussing the spatial-temporal change patterns and the driving mechanisms of NPP in a regional vegetation ecosystem not only are of significance to understand the response of this ecosystem to climate change, but also can provide a scientific basis for ecological environment protection, plant yield estimation, resource exploitation, effective management of natural resources, and formulation of the corresponding social and economic development strategies. The unique geographical location, altitude, climate and geomorphological conditions of the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau in China result in various climatic and ecosystem types. As a special geographic unit, the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau exhibits an important role in regulating and indicating global change; it is considered to be the ''natural laboratory'' for studies of climate change in the world.
research objective: Therefore, in this study, a gravity center model was introduced to analyze the spatial and temporal change patterns and the driving mechanisms of NPP in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau from 2000 to 2015 in combination with the conventional analysis methods. Furthermore, the relative effects of climate change and human activities on the NPP changes were also quantitatively distinguished. This study provides data and theoretical support to reveal the evolution patterns of the ecosystems in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau and the response mechanisms of the ecosystems to global change.
challenges: Although some previous studies have used conventional analysis methods (such as the correlation analysis model) to investigate the NPP change patterns in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, the relationships between NPP and climate factors and the relative effects of climate change and human activities on the NPP changes remain unclear.
dataset: The NPP during 2000–2015 obtained from the MOD17A3 dataset is available at https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/. The spatial and temporal resolutions were 1 km and 1 a, respectively. The data (including the daily precipitation and mean daily temperature) of 229 meteorological stations in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau and its surrounding areas, were obtained from the China Meteorological Data Network (http://data.cma.cn/).
findings: The average annual NPP in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau showed a decreasing trend from the southeast to the northwest during 2000–2015. With respect to the inter-annual changes, the average annual NPP exhibited a fluctuating upward trend from 2000 to 2015, with a steep increase observed in 2005 and a high fluctuation observed from 2005 to 2015. In the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, the regions with the increase in NPP (change rate higher than 10%) were mainly concentrated in the Three-River Source Region, the northern Hengduan Mountains, the middle and lower reaches of the Yarlung Zangbo River, and the eastern parts of the North Tibet Plateau, whereas the regions with the decrease in NPP (change rate lower than –10%) were mainly concentrated in the upper reaches of the Yarlung Zangbo River and the Ali Plateau. The gravity center of NPP in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau has moved southwestward during 2000–2015, indicating that the increment and growth rate of NPP in the southwestern part is greater than those of NPP in the northeastern part. Further, a significant correlation was observed between NPP and climate factors in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau. The regions exhibiting a significant correlation between NPP and precipitation were mainly located in the central and eastern Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, and the regions exhibiting a significant correlation between NPP and temperature were mainly located in the southern and eastern Qinghai–Tibet Plateau. Furthermore, the relative effects of climate change and human activities on the NPP changes in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau exhibited significant spatial differences in three types of zones, i.e., the climate change-dominant zone, the human activity-dominant zone, and the climate change and human activity interaction zone.

Verification.Question: Does the use of ArcGIS 10.3's Cokriging method ensure the spatial resolution of 1x1 km for interpolated climate data?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the key ecological asset driving factors included in a dataset for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: topography, climate, soil, vegetation, human activities, land use types

Concept Completion.Question: Where is the digital elevation model (DEM) data used in a dataset for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau sourced from?
Concept Completion.Answer: Chinese Academy of Sciences Resource and Environment Science Data Center

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection method is used to interpolate annual average temperature and precipitation data in a dataset for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that includes both climate data and human activity factors for the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Example.Answer: A dataset that includes both climate data and human activity factors for the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau is the dataset containing information from 229 meteorological stations in the region, which includes daily precipitation, mean daily temperature, and data on human activities such as population and GDP, categorized into levels.

Example.Question: What is an example of a data interpolation method used to process climatic data for ecological studies in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a data interpolation method used to process climatic data for ecological studies in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau is the Cokriging method, utilized to interpolate annual average temperature, precipitation, sunshine hours, and accumulated temperature, maintaining a spatial resolution of 1×1 km.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how vegetation data is sourced and its temporal resolution for studies on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of how vegetation data is sourced for studies on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau is the use of the MOD17A3H dataset, which provides net primary productivity (NPP) data with a temporal resolution of 1 year and a spatial resolution of 1 km.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of the ecological asset driving factors dataset for the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau from 2000 to 2020?
Feature Specification.Answer: terrain, climate, soil, vegetation, human activities, land use types, spatial resolution of 1 km, temporal resolution of 1 year, digital elevation model (DEM), daily precipitation, average temperature, sunshine duration, Cokriging interpolation, ArcGIS 10.3, spatial resolution of 1×1 km, annual precipitation levels, temperature levels, population levels, GDP levels

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the methods used to interpolate climate data in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau ecological asset dataset?
Feature Specification.Answer: Cokriging method, ArcGIS 10.3, spatial resolution of 1×1 km, climate parameters divided into levels

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features of the Net Primary Productivity (NPP) dataset used in studies concerning the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: 1 km spatial resolution, 1 year temporal resolution

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of the meteorological data collected from the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
How many meteorological stations provided data for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and its surrounding areas?
Over how many years does the NPP data from the MOD17A3 dataset span?

Definition.Question: What does 'interpolation method' mean in the context of climate data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of climate data collection, 'interpolation method' refers to a mathematical technique used to estimate unknown values that fall within the range of a discrete set of known data points. Specifically, the Cokriging method is a type of interpolation used to estimate spatial variables like annual average temperature, annual precipitation, sunshine hours, and accumulated temperature, maintaining a spatial resolution of 1x1 km.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'removing outliers' in data preprocessing?
Definition.Answer: 'Removing outliers' in data preprocessing refers to the process of identifying and eliminating data points that significantly deviate from the rest of the dataset. This is done to improve data quality and analysis accuracy, as outliers can skew results and lead to incorrect conclusions. In this context, Microsoft Excel is used to remove outliers from population and GDP data, categorizing them into five levels.

Definition.Question: What does 'natural breaks method' mean in classifying environmental data?
Definition.Answer: The 'natural breaks method' in classifying environmental data involves dividing continuous data into distinct categories or classes where there are significant jumps in the data values. This method is used to classify annual average precipitation, accumulated temperature, annual average temperature, solar radiation, and elevation into six levels, and slope and aspect into nine and ten levels, respectively.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for climate factors in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau compare to those used for vegetation data collection in terms of spatial and temporal resolution?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods for climate factors involve using data from 229 meteorological stations, which are then interpolated using Cokriging to maintain a spatial resolution of 1 km. In contrast, the vegetation data collection uses the MOD17A3 dataset, which directly provides NPP data with a spatial resolution of 1 km and a temporal resolution of 1 year.

Interpretation.Question: What does the spatial distribution pattern of net primary productivity (NPP) from 2000 to 2015 suggest about the ecological variations across the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The average annual NPP in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau showed a decreasing trend from the southeast to the northwest during 2000–2015. This pattern suggests ecological variations, with some regions experiencing an increase in NPP mainly concentrated in the Three-River Source Region, the northern Hengduan Mountains, and the middle and lower reaches of the Yarlung Zangbo River. Conversely, regions with a decrease in NPP were concentrated in the upper reaches of the Yarlung Zangbo River and the Ali Plateau.

Interpretation.Question: What can the movement of the gravity center of NPP from 2000 to 2015 reveal about the relative impact of climate change versus human activities on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The southwestward movement of the gravity center of NPP from 2000 to 2015 indicates that the increment and growth rate of NPP in the southwestern part is greater than in the northeastern part. This movement suggests significant spatial differences in the relative effects of climate change and human activities on NPP changes, revealing zones where climate change dominates, where human activity is dominant, and where both factors interact.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a focus on distinguishing between the effects of climate change and human activities on NPP changes in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Distinguishing between the effects of climate change and human activities on NPP changes is crucial due to the significant spatial differences observed across the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau. This differentiation helps in understanding the ecosystem's response mechanisms and provides a scientific basis for ecological environment protection and resource management.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What leads to the use of natural breakpoint classification in categorizing ecological factors like precipitation and elevation in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The use of natural breakpoint classification is driven by the need to handle the complex and varied ecological factors such as precipitation and elevation across the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau. This method allows for the categorization of these factors into meaningful classes, facilitating more accurate analysis and interpretation of ecological data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using interpolation methods like Cokriging with a 1×1 km spatial resolution on the accuracy and utility of datasets for climate change studies in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using interpolation methods like Cokriging with a 1×1 km spatial resolution helps in maintaining consistency and precision in spatial data representation. It allows for a detailed analysis of climatic variables such as temperature, precipitation, and solar radiation across the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau. This can enhance the understanding of spatial-temporal change patterns and the driving mechanisms of ecological assets, thus providing a robust dataset for climate change studies and ecological research.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences arise from removing outliers using tools like Microsoft Excel when preparing datasets for assessing ecosystem health on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Removing outliers using tools like Microsoft Excel can lead to cleaner and more reliable datasets, potentially reducing noise and improving the accuracy of analysis regarding ecosystem health. However, it might also result in the loss of valuable data that could indicate rare or extreme events. This balance is crucial for ensuring that the dataset accurately reflects the ecosystem's conditions and supports robust ecological assessments and predictions in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind collecting meteorological data from 229 stations in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, and how does this contribute to understanding ecosystem changes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective of collecting meteorological data from 229 stations in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau is to analyze and understand the response of the regional vegetation ecosystem to climate change. This data helps provide a scientific basis for ecological environment protection, plant yield estimation, and resource exploitation by examining the spatial-temporal change patterns and driving mechanisms of NPP.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can ArcGIS 10.3's Cokriging method be utilized to interpolate climate data for ecological asset studies in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: ArcGIS 10.3's Cokriging method is applied to interpolate climate data such as annual average temperature, annual precipitation, sunshine hours, and accumulated temperature. The spatial resolution is maintained at 1×1 km, allowing for detailed spatial analysis of climatic factors impacting the ecological assets in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to classify and grade ecological asset driving factors like precipitation, temperature, and elevation in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The natural breaks method is used to classify and grade annual average precipitation, accumulated temperature, annual average temperature, solar radiation, and elevation into six levels. Slope and aspect are divided into nine and ten levels, respectively, and population and GDP data are graded into five levels, facilitating a nuanced analysis of ecological asset driving factors.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What data preprocessing techniques are used to ensure the reliability of datasets collected from various sources related to the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Microsoft Excel is utilized to remove outliers from datasets, ensuring the reliability of data collected from various sources, including meteorological stations and ecological datasets. This preprocessing step is crucial for maintaining data quality and accuracy in the analysis of ecological assets and climatic factors.

Enablement.Question: How do methods like Cokriging enable the interpolation of meteorological data for ecological research?
Enablement.Answer: Cokriging methods are used in conjunction with ArcGIS to interpolate meteorological data such as annual average temperature, precipitation, and solar radiation. This enables the creation of spatially resolved climate datasets that maintain a resolution of 1x1 km, which is crucial for analyzing ecological changes and patterns in regions like the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.

Enablement.Question: Which conditions and methods are necessary to ensure the removal of anomalies in ecological datasets?
Enablement.Answer: To ensure the removal of anomalies, the use of data processing tools like Microsoft Excel is necessary. These tools are used to filter and clean datasets, such as those related to population and GDP, by identifying and removing outliers to maintain data integrity for ecological research.

Expectation.Question: Why might spatial interpolation methods like Cokriging be expected to improve the accuracy of climate data collection in complex terrains such as the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The unique geographical location, altitude, and geomorphological conditions of the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau result in various climatic and ecosystem types. Using spatial interpolation methods like Cokriging helps account for these complex spatial patterns by providing a more detailed and accurate representation of climate data across the plateau's diverse terrain.

Expectation.Question: Why might the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau's role as a 'natural laboratory' for climate change studies lead to expectations for high variability in collected dataset outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: The Qinghai–Tibet Plateau's unique geographical and climatic conditions make it a significant area for studying global change. As a 'natural laboratory,' it encompasses diverse climatic and ecosystem types, leading to expectations of high variability in dataset outcomes due to the complex interactions between climate change, human activities, and ecosystem responses across different regions of the plateau.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of the Cokriging method used for interpolating meteorological data in terms of spatial resolution and accuracy within the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The Cokriging method is used with a spatial resolution of 1x1 km for interpolating meteorological data like annual average temperature, precipitation, and solar radiation. This method is suitable for maintaining consistent spatial resolution, but its effectiveness in terms of accuracy would depend on the density and distribution of the 229 meteorological stations across the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and surrounding areas.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how data interpolation methods, like Cokriging, are effectively applied to meteorological data in geographical studies.
Assertion.Answer: In the field, Cokriging is used within ArcGIS 10.3 to interpolate annual average temperature, annual precipitation, sunshine duration, and accumulated temperature data. This method helps maintain spatial resolution at 1×1 km, allowing researchers to analyze climate patterns across the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the classification of climate and geographical variables is determined for ecological data analysis.
Assertion.Answer: In ecological data analysis, climate and geographical variables such as annual precipitation, temperature, solar radiation, and elevation are classified into different levels using natural breakpoint methods. This classification helps in understanding the ecological impacts and variations across different regions of the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the data collection methods used for acquiring climatic data and their interpolation techniques for enhancing spatial resolution in ecological studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: The climatic data for the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, such as daily precipitation, daily average temperature, and sunshine duration, were obtained from 229 meteorological stations in the region and its surrounding areas, sourced from the China Meteorological Data Network. The data were interpolated using the Cokriging method in ArcGIS 10.3 to enhance their spatial resolution to 1 km². This method involved interpolating annual average temperature, annual precipitation, sunshine duration, and accumulated temperature.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in differentiating the impact of climate change and human activities on regional Net Primary Productivity (NPP) changes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Distinguishing the relative effects of climate change and human activities on NPP changes poses challenges, as conventional analysis methods, such as correlation analysis models, often leave the relationships between NPP and climate factors unclear. The study employs a gravity center model to analyze spatial and temporal patterns of NPP in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, aiming to quantitatively distinguish these effects and reveal ecosystem response mechanisms.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be integrated to study the spatial-temporal changes in ecosystem health indicators other than NPP on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: In addition to the MOD17A3 dataset used for studying NPP, potential datasets include digital elevation models (DEM) from the Chinese Academy of Sciences, demographic and GDP data categorized into five levels, and various layers representing terrain, climate, soil, vegetation, and human activities. These datasets can be used to study other indicators of ecosystem health, as they provide comprehensive information on the driving factors of ecological assets on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.
